Award.AbstractNarration:
Three rather ambitious projects are proposed in the area of geometric
group theory. The first is inspired by Zlil Sela's geometric solution
of Tarski's logic problem. The PI and Mladen Bestvina plan to complete
their program to solve by geometric means two forty-year-old problems
of Mal'cev. They also propose to generalize their methods and provide
an alternate proof to the Tarski problem. The second project, joint
with Michael Handel, is to solve the conjugacy problem for the outer
automorphism group Out(F) of a free group F. Much of the research in
this area is driven by the similarities between linear groups, surface
mapping class groups, and Out(F). The conjugacy problem has been
solved for these other two classes. The final project, again joint
with Mladen Bestvina, is to better understand the geometry of outer
automorphism groups of free groups. In particular, it is proposed to show
that a complex analogous to the curve complex in the mapping class
group setting is word hyperbolic.

Three projects are proposed in the area of geometric group
theory. Geometric group theory is a relatively young branch of
mathematics in which problems from other areas of mathematics are
reformulated and then solved in geometric terms. This approach has
been successful in areas that are sometimes viewed as distant from
geometry. For example, Zlil Sela used geometric methods to solve an
old logic problem of Tarski. Inspired by Sela's methods, the PI and
Mladen Bestvina propose to solve two old logic problems of
Mal'cev. Group theory is another area where these methods have been
particularly successful. Groups are ubiquitous in math and the
sciences. The set of symmetries of a molecule is an example. There is
an important class of groups called "free groups" from which all other
groups can be constructed. The set of symmetries of a free group F is
another important group, denoted Out(F), which has been the subject of
much current interest. The PI proposes two other projects focusing on
Out(F). In one, he and Michael Handel propose to solve an old and
fundamental problem on Out(F), namely that its conjugacy problem is
solvable. In the other project, the PI and Bestvina propose to better
understand the intrinsic geometry of Out(F).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research: The work supported by the grant is in the field of geometric group theory, a relatively new area of math that is attracting many young researchers. For example, "Young Geometric Group Theory", a yearly conference series founded about four years ago to introduce graduate students and post-docs to a broad range of topics in the field, has averaged over 100 participants per meeting.

In geometric group theory, problems from other areas of math are recast (and then hopefully solved) in geometric terms. As an elementary — but illustrative — example, the set of numbers (an algebraic object) is profitably viewed as points on the number line (a geometric object). This approach has been successful in solving problems from areas as diverse as group theory and logic. In fact, problems from these two areas are the focus of the projects supported by this grant.

Groups are algebraic objects that appear in geometry as sets of symmetries. For example, the set of symmetries of an equilateral triangle is a finite group with six elements: three rotations (including rotation by zero degrees) and three reflections. The classes of groups studied in this grant’s projects are infinite and are called “outer automorphism groups of free groups.” These groups have been classically studied and are of intense current interest, in part because of the success of geometric approaches. Outcomes during the grant period include the publication of two papers with Mladen Bestvina. The main result of the first is that these groups are symmetry groups of spaces with an important property called “hyperbolicity.” The second explores consequences of this first result and related results of Michael Handel and Lee Mosher.

The work with Bestvina was focused on global properties of these outer automorphism groups. Work with Michael Handel supported by the same grant was focused on geometric representations of elements of these outer automorphism groups with a goal of solving the “conjugacy problem” for this class. The conjugacy problem is a famous problem that can be posed for any class of groups; the existence (or not) of a solution is a measure how well that class of groups is understood. Handel and the PI are optimistic that they have found a solution to the conjugacy problem for an important subclass of these outer automorphism groups and are preparing a manuscript with this solution. During the grant period, they submitted a paper showing that every element of these outer automorphism groups has a particularly nice geometric representative that can be found algorithmically. It is anticipated that this algorithmic result will be needed for a solution to the full conjugacy problem.

In another direction, Zlil Sela's geometric solution to the Tarski problem in logic has generated much excitement in geometric group theory. During the grant period, Bestvina, Pei Wang (a graduate student of the PI), and the PI worked on an alternate approach to part of Sela’s solution which should make it more accessible.

Broader Impact: During the period of this grant, the PI directed the theses of two Rutgers-Newark graduate students: Greg Fein and Pei Wang. Thesis topics were directly related to the projects supported by the grant.   Also, the PI lectured extensively on project outcomes and on geometric group theory in general.
